div1.p: ON CUBAN SANITATION.

Washington Government Officials
Paying Attention to Cuban
Board of Health.
(Special Correspondence.)

Washington, August 30.--While
there is now less talk about the yel-
low fever in Cuba, than existed a
week ago, the consideration of the
problem is receiving much atention
and the Washington authorities feel
almost as active an interest in it,
perhaps as does Governor Magoon
himself.

While the mosquito theory is re-
ally no longer a theory but an ac-
cepted fact, yet where appears to ex-
ist in the minds of some, who are
men of great learning in medicine,
that the mosquito is not all there is
responsible for the disease. While
no other solution is presented, the
belief appears to be strong that the
first cause of the disease has not
yet been discovered.

With the nationalizing of the
Board of Health of Cuba, it is likely
that a closed study will be made of
the disease, and the causes of the re-
cent outbreak of the disease may be
explained. If the mosquito is res-
ponsible, how is it then, that the
Island could have been so free of it
and then have it break out as it did.
Surely the mosquito cannot be blam-
ed for the transmission of the disease
after so long a time had elapsed since
the prvious cases, unless they can
transmit the germs to their poster-
ity unto the third and fourth genera-
tion, or even to more remote
branches.

If it is not proven that during the
interval there was yellow fever, per-
haps of a milder type, at these places
where it developed after more than
six months had elapsed since the pre-
viously known case, then it will be
plain that there are other influences
than the mosquito which tend to con-
tinue the disease. The explanation
given that there undoubtedly existed
cases in those small towns in Ma-
tanzas province which were never re-
ported as such, is quite likely to be
true. The known objection of any
people not used to sanitation, or to
the exercise of the more advanced
hygienic precautions, an objection
which the Cubans have exhibited to
a marked degree, not only in this in-
tervention, but in the first interven-
tion. On both occasions they have
scornfully shown their condemna-
tion of sanitation both in their re-
signed manner of submitting to it,
and their indifference to the work;
and there have been some who have
been frank enough to say that it
was all foolishness and did not
amount to anything. Some of them
have taken the matter very sorely,
but those who are said to have been
sorest, are the Spanish element of
the population.

This easily explained, because the
Cubans have always been under the
Spanish regime and have had to sub-
mit to their dictates. They have
learned, through successive genera-
tions, the lesson of bowing or at
least appearing to bow to the gov-
ernment of the island. The Span-
iard, on the other hand, after so
long a reign do not relish having to
take orders, particularly when they
regard them as a useless display of
authority.

It is thought that with the ques-
tion of health in the hands of Major
Kean yellow fever will have a closer
scrutiny than it has ever had before
because he will have first hand data
from all of the Cuban towns, can or-
der any investigation he chooses,
and can have the power to do just a
he pleases in carrying on his studies.
It is a splendid opportunity for a
comparatively young physician, and
there is no doubt that he will avail
himself of it. What is of great in-
terest is the exact origin of the dis-
ease. What gives it its first start?
Surely not the mosquito, and if he
does, where does he get it?

It is plain to many that we either
do not know the habits of the mos-
quito, or a great injustice is being
done that insect by imposing upon it
the full culpablity of propagating
the disease. The cause is believed
to lie in certain bad sanitary condi-
tions, which reduce the water in
which the mosquitoes are hatched to
a peculiar condition, which start
them out charged with serum, some
having it probably in a greater or
lesser degree.

Let us take, for instance the good
work being done on the Isthmus of
Panama, by the American sanitary
officers in that zone. They have
relegated yellow fever to the rear
at least they have that accomplish-
ment to their credit just now. It
is true that the work they have done
there has been phenomenal and has
cost an immense amount of money,
but they have made the place healthy
and wonderfully so, if one goes
back to the days when the French
were working on the canal.

Not counting any of the native
population, simply those Americans
and natives employed by the Amer-
ican government in the work on the
canal, there are 38,000 souls. During
the month of last July, there were
only 1,097 cases of sickness, while
during the month of July, 1906, with
28,000 workmen there were 1,107,
cases of sickness. For July, 1907,
the percentage of deaths among the
white employees, was 16, while
among the colored employees it was
42. For the month of July, 1906,
however, the death rate for the
whites was 30, and for the colored
72.

This data is interesting, because
recent figures in this city give the
death rate of the whites at 16.9 and
the colored death rate at 23.8. The
death rate at Havana is probably a
little greater than that of this city.

For more than twenty months
there has not been a case of yellow
fever at Panama, the last occurring
there in November, 1905. The last
case of yellow fever on the Isth-
mus was in May, 1906, fifteen
months ago. During July, only four
Americans, white, employed by the
Canal Commission, died and two of
them were accidentally drowned.
“NOTE FOR THE PRESS.”

Taft Denies He Said Last Cabinet
Was Dishonest--Nobody Says
That He Said It.

The following statement for the
press was issued from the Palace
this morning:

“Washington dispatches recently
published in Havana asserted that
the American government had proof
that the members of the late cabinet
of President Palma were defaulters
and guilty of dishonest practices dur-
ing the revolution of 1906. These
statements came to the attention of
Secretary Taft, and, thereupon, he
cabled Governor Magoon as fol-
lows:

“‘The statement that the Ameri-
can government has proof that cab-
inet officers and President Palma
were defaulters or dishonest during
the revolution of 1906 is entirely un-
founded. No evidence of this kind
has ever been brought to my at-
tention, nor have I any reason to
suppose that the members of Presi-
dent Palma's cabinet were defaultors
or dishonest. You can make this
statement wthout qualification, and
give it publication.’”

The above statement was no doubt
called forth by correspondence which
recently appeared in The Lucna,
from its Washington correspondence.
In this correspondence there was no
charge made against the honesty or
square dealings of any member of
President Palma's cabinet during
the revolution of 1906. No direct
charge was made that President Pal-
ma was dishonest. But it will be
noticed that Secretary Taft does not
follow the correspondent's statement
that “a late official” of the Cuban
government was charged with queer
practices, and that it was put up to
him in pretty strong terms. The
Lucha is afraid that Secretary Taft
was not first shown the correspon-
dence he was called upon to de-
nounce.
YELLOW FEVER SITUATION

Reports from Cienfuegos state that
only two cases of yellow fever are
now under treatment there. No
deaths have occurred.
There are two cases in Havana.
WANTS HIS MONEY.

Eugenio Lopez, who lives at Ar-
senal 34, has received three very
threatening anonymous letters. They
were written by “El Silencio,” and
demanded money from him, which
they declared, if not forthcoming
would be to the peril of the recip-
ient of the letters.

Señor Lopez has delivered the let-
ters to the judge who has ordered an
investigation.
CUBA COMPANY MEETING

It is announced that the annual
meetng of the stockholders of the
Cuba Railroad Company will be held
in Jersey City on the 18th inst.

Sir William Van Horne. Herbert
C. Lakin, Theodore C. Hall and
Franklin B. Lord are requesting
proxies to be sent them.

At the meeting in question a full
board of directors is to be elected,
and will attend to such other busi-
ness as may come before the meet-
ing.
Arrived in New York.

New York, Sept. 3.--Vessels ar-
riving in this port from Cuba were:
The Saratoga and Antilla from Ha-
vana, the Camaguey from Guan-
tanamo.
RANDOM NOTES.

It makes a great deal of difference
to some “persons” whether they are
jostled by other “persons” who work
for a salary, or simply by ones who
work for wages.

did not specially need the endorse-
ment from Secretary Taft that they
